hints.content: Start by understanding the input format. You are given an array of integers representing student scores. Each score can be thought of as a unique identifier for a student.
Think about what it means for a student to be replaced. When a student is replaced, their score is no longer part of the array. How will you keep track of which scores have been replaced?
Consider how you might count the number of replacements. You might want to maintain a count of how many times each score appears in the array. This could help you determine when a replacement occurs.
You should also think about the order of scores. If two students have the same score, how will you handle that situation? Will the first student be replaced, or will it depend on some other criteria?
As you work through the problem, consider edge cases. For example, what happens if the input array is empty or contains only one score? How will your logic handle these scenarios?
You might want to use a data structure that allows for easy counting and replacement. A dictionary or hash map could be useful for mapping scores to their counts.
Think about how to iterate through the array. You could use a loop to check each score, but consider how you will update the counts in your data structure as you go.
Remember to return the correct format. If the problem specifies a particular output format, make sure your final answer matches that format exactly.
Consider how you will handle ties. If multiple students have the same score, will you replace all of them, or only the first one? Make sure your logic is clear on this point.
Finally, think about the time complexity of your solution. If you are using nested loops, it might be inefficient for larger arrays. Can you optimize your approach to reduce the number of iterations?

questionNotes: Input is an array of integers representing student scores.
Each score can be unique or repeated; handle duplicates carefully.
Consider edge cases like empty arrays or arrays with one element.
Output format must match the specified requirements exactly.
Pay attention to how ties are handled when replacing students.
